page.title: 04The Rochdale Canal
page.content: The canal locks have been reopened to let the barges pass once again. A {canal}was built in Manchester in 1761. Barges could travel along the Rivers Aire & Calder in Yorkshire almost as far as Sowerby Bridge, so they could nearly travel from Hull to Liverpool. A meeting was held in Hebden Bridge to consider building a canal to join the 33 miles from Sowerby Bridge to Manchester. Â£200000 was raised but not everyone wanted a canal and Parliament said no. However,those who wanted a canal asked Wm.Jessop to survey the route. In April 1794 permission was given to build it. By August 1798 the canal was opened from Sowerby Bridge to Todmorden and finally completed by 1802. It had 92 locks and was used by barges up to 74 feet long and 14 feet wide.
